G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, which grants the District Court concurrent jurisdiction over tort cases where the damages claimed do not exceed $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Newton, Massachusetts.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence is established when the defendant owed a duty of care to the plaintiff, the defendant breached that duty, the breach caused the plaintiff’s injuries, and the plaintiff suffered actual damages as a result of the injuries.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly sets out the elements the plaintiffs must prove in a negligence claim, including breach of a duty to use reasonable care, causation, and actual loss/damages. While it condenses duty and breach into “breach of the duty to use reasonable care,” the structure of the elements matches the proposition: duty, breach, causation, and actual damages. The court’s analysis of why summary judgment is appropriate turns on plaintiffs’ failure to prove causation, underscoring that these elements are required under Massachusetts law.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 756 (1984).proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of care both as the owner of a dog and as a user of the park to act reasonably to avoid creating foreseeable risks of harm.
Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 756 (1984).support_reasoning: The case deals with whether a town (as public employer) owes a duty, through its police officers, to members of the motoring public to act reasonably in dealing with intoxicated drivers under the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act. It does not concern duties of a private defendant as dog owner or as a user of a park, nor does it address premises liability or animal ownership. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for a duty of care arising from dog ownership or park usage.
Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 756 (1984).relevant_excerpt: "We conclude that there is a special relationship between a police officer who negligently fails to remove an intoxicated motorist from the highway, and a member of the public who suffers injury as a result of that failure. The statutes which establish police responsibilities in such circumstances evidence a legislative intent to protect both intoxicated persons and other users of the highway."

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7 173.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to control his dog and by violating local and state leash laws, which are intended to protect members of the public, such as Plaintiff, from harm.

Fahey v. Rockwell Graphics Sys., Inc., 2.raw_text: Fahey v. Rockwell Graphics Sys., Inc., 20 Mass. App. Ct. 642, 647 (1985)
Fahey v. Rockwell Graphics Sys., Inc., 2.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to control his dog and by violating local and state leash laws, which are intended to protect members of the public, such as Plaintiff, from harm.
Fahey v. Rockwell Graphics Sys., Inc., 2.case_name: Fahey v. Rockwell Graphic Systems, Inc.
Fahey v. Rockwell Graphics Sys., Inc., 2.support_reasoning: The case concerns negligent design, breach of warranty, and negligent instruction relating to a printing press; it does not involve dogs, dog owners, or leash laws. There is no discussion of duties arising from animal control or statutory/local leash requirements, nor any statement that violation of such laws constitutes breach of a duty to protect the public. Thus it cannot serve as authority for the leash-law-based duty described in the proposition.
Fahey v. Rockwell Graphics Sys., Inc., 2.relevant_excerpt: A manufacturer is under a duty to design a machine with reasonable care... The product must be designed with reasonable care to eliminate avoidable dangers... It is, therefore, incumbent on the designer to “anticipate the environment in which its product will be used, and ... design against the reasonably foreseeable risks attending the product’s use in that setting.”

Galluzzi v. Beverly Enters., Inc., 383 M.raw_text: Galluzzi v. Beverly Enters., Inc., 383 Mass. 707, 711 (1981)
Galluzzi v. Beverly Enters., Inc., 383 M.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that allowing his dog to roam off-leash in an area frequented by joggers and pedestrians created a foreseeable risk of harm.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 57 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s negligence in failing to control his dog was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s negligence in failing to control his dog being the proximate cause of injuries. Mullins v. Pine Manor College is a premises/security case about a college’s alleged negligent security and locking systems leading to a rape, and this excerpt is a dissent arguing that proximate cause was *not* established. It neither involves a dog nor supports a finding that negligence proximately caused the plaintiff’s injuries; instead, it emphasizes the speculative nature of causation and that the plaintiff failed to prove proximate cause.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, the plaintiff failed to show that the defendants’ negligent failure to exclude possible intruders from the plaintiff’s dormitory proximately caused her injury. … The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ … In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury.”

Kourouvacilis v. Gen. Motors Corp., 410.raw_text: Kourouvacilis v. Gen. Motors Corp., 410 Mass. 706, 716 (1991)
Kourouvacilis v. Gen. Motors Corp., 410.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries and damages were foreseeable consequences of Defendant’s actions.
Kourouvacilis v. Gen. Motors Corp., 410.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address foreseeability of injuries or damages as a consequence of the defendant’s actions. Instead, it focuses on summary judgment standards and the plaintiff’s inability to produce evidence of a defect or causation. There is no discussion of whether the plaintiff’s injuries were a foreseeable result of any conduct by the defendants, so the case does not support the stated proposition.
Kourouvacilis v. Gen. Motors Corp., 410.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff had the burden of proof at trial on the question whether her alleged personal injury and property loss were due to a defect in the manufacture or design of her automobile. … [T]he plaintiff’s appellate argument is without merit. … [E]ven without expert testimony, she can [not] prove her case by invoking the doctrine of res ipsa loquitur. The common experience of mankind in no way suggests that an unexplained fire in an automobile six years after its purchase was caused by a defect in the vehicle that had existed from the time of the vehicle’s manufacture or sale.”
